comments.commentBody: The intention may have been to mean Baptists who are Americans but again good intentions aren't enough. The distinction is particularly relevant in light of the reason for the split between the two Baptist conventions. ( mentioned by TEH #48).  The attempt to compact meaning into a headline occasionally results in bloopers.  This was one.  Sorry 'bout that.

In 1981, I was in a deep coma; as far as I knew, I was conscious but I couldn't speak—and didn't know why—because I had a tracheotomy tube in place. As far as I know, the hospital staff simply watered me like a plant until I "came to" four weeks later.

I'm trying to figure out from the article whether the author means "persistent vegetative state" or simply "vegetative." I feel there is promise for this technology, simply because there are comatose patients who feel "locked up" and frustrated; I was one. I was aware of my surroundings and recognized visitors; how amazing it would have been to be able to communicate with these people who thought I was asleep!
Is it wedge issue time already?
Screw civility. that's how progressive thinkers allowed the nutjobs to run the country into the ground in the first place. Its time for hard words and tough action.

Hmmmmm..... The ultra left is still in denial over losing the Holy Grail of liberal seats in the Senate. Just as they are in denial about the practical effect of he stimulus (nil), other than allowing some local governments to make payroll for a few more months. Job creation in the private sector is non existent. Just as they are in denial about the root cause of Brown's victory.... recognition of the charade that Obama, Reid and Pelosi represent in DC. So far, all the country has seen of hope and change are far out ideas that can't be paid for, much less effectively enacted, and a pontificating triumvirate who don't feel they have anyone to answer to.

They still don't get it. Lip service is the most transparent this bunch has been about anything, and the voters of the US "NO" it. Obama engages the opposition, and brags about it? Phoney baloney!
Then tells dems to not quit fighting? Whats wrong with that picture? Obama trying to capture the
Scott Brown spotlight is amusing, but also says worlds about his character and agenda.

November can't come soon enough. The new faces in Congress will avert this bankrupt disaster.

"China talks a tough game but I suspect that when they see major export markets in trouble, they start the back room negotiations."

China has hit the trifecta. The world's crisis comes at a time when China's domestic spending was already beginning to ramp-up; thus mitigating need of sustaining export levels. Does the average tea-partier know how they helped fund 6000 miles of high-speed rail in China?

http://www.financialpost.com...

A word of warning from my own experience - transferring to a hard drive is not enough.  I did that with 15 years of family video only to have the hard drive crash a year later before I got around to buying a second hard drive and backing up the first.  And I lost more than just the transferred video because I had also logged lots of information (in Final Cut).  I still have the tapes and will probably transfer them all again, but if you have any advice on backing up, would love to hear it.

Hear ... HEAR! Right on, David. Ever spent any time on genealogy work? In that activity, you work for weeks just to find out when and where great granny was born. Now we have these media, however dated, that bring the oldsters right in our living room. In addition, our lives are captured with the places and personalities - and hair cuts - that you mentioned. I'm still using Digital 8, and we make a Video Yearbook each year - and you're right: they get better as you get older.

Dave, keep making those home videos! I'm 67 years old and I just had the 16mm films my DAD shot of us in the early 50s digitized. It was important to MY KIDS to be able to see them!

I can't help wondering what value it would have been if the colonist for this country had been able to film every day life. Wouldn't you love to see a home movie of Ben Franklin?

Look how important old pictures are to people doing family ancestries. Imagine your great great great grandchildren trying to figure out where they came from and who this ancestor was that wrote for a Newspaper (whatever that was?).
David--what format is the film in of the editor you referred to who can't find a machine to show it? Is it Sony 3/4", or Beta? Might be able to help. richardlukin@rcn.com

Looking for confirmation that you recommend both MiniDV tapes and hard drive storage of video home movies.  Is this because of your previous experiences with DVD files fading after a few storage years?  Were these DVD files on "archival" disks with gold reflective layers?  GREAT ARTICLE
Thanks for the article "Why We Make Home Videos." It brought back the memory of getting lost in all those photos of my kids taken so long ago. They are priceless.

I am in the middle of a similar experience with about 4,000 color slides documenting the first 30 years of our marriage.   I find that there are a half-dozen that I have to share with family out of every weeks labor.  When I finish, they will fit on a thumb drive.
This is one of the nicest techonology posts I have read for a long time.

I remember (probably badly) a psychology report on home videos. The insight I took from it: home videos help kids relate to older and younger people; siblings, relatives, people in their community. The child can see that they were younger and how they were at that age - their little brother or sister doesn't seem so stupid or feeble. And the child can see that they are catching up to their older sibling/s, their parents are turning into their grandparents and they will turn into their parents.

Also, for stills, the iPhoto to iDVD pairing is fantastic. I like to make a slide show with music and keep the original images on the DVD-ROM portion for printing and back-up. Send a copy to the grandparents and you have grateful parents, in-laws, and an off site back-up too.

Thanks to Apple for the iLife suite - I can't think of a better piece of software for families.

My first photos of my school mates in Brooklyn rehearsing for "Cyrano de Bergerac - in 1950. Korea in 52, Japan in 53, Australia in '57 to '64 - Galapagos, Gabon geographic center - all over Canada - off-shore drilling rigs and production platforms in the North Sea ---et-cet ad nauseum.

How to digitize boxes of prints and slides without spending the rest of my few years and dollars to capture as you describe?

David, what is the "Sony videotape format that disappeared ages ago"? Tape machines for most formats aren't too difficult to find, unless you're talking about Sony's CV format (which died in the 60's) or 2-inch. But it's not too hard (especially in NYC) to find machines for 1-inch, 3/4-inch, BetaCam, or BetaSP.

Listen, while I have some - very short - home movies from the early Sixties, these did not include sound. Seeing my extended family again as they were 50 years ago is an extraordinarily powerful experience... of course, even with these films (converted all to mpeg files and DVDs) what I lust to hear again are the conversations, and that won't happen of course. Dinner table, picnic table, living room conversations. What most people don't realize is that, yes, our genetics is a powerful part of what we inherit from our parents etc, but there are mannerisms and speech patterns, even the way that we approach life in general that are transmitted from earlier generations. I discovered a family photo album that was started soon after the Civil War (with a few obituaries) which had professionally done photos - studio - on cardboard. From the names and locations of the studios, I was able to determine how my family moved from the East Coast to the Midwest starting in the early 1800s. When I was young, this wouldn't have meant much but by age 50, understanding the mixtures of forces and personalities that essentially made me and my generation of the family was more important. These videos will be watched in the future. Recently I sat down and did several DVDs about my recollections of high school in the Sixties (not the 'right wing talk show' version of the Sixties, but the REAL Sixties) which I titled "The Laughing Dead" because the theme was around those members of my high school class who have passed away. Our generation has precious little of the sound film of our experiences, so the best that can be done is recollections and stills, something along the lines of a Ken Burns documentary. If you make these things, people will watch, eventually... and so will you.

Funny you should write about old movies...
I am in the midst of converting 30-40 year old 8mm to video. Using very low tech method: project onto screen and Flip video on tripod. Slight jutter, but otherwise effective -- and cheap.

Two experiences to share - I am a photographer, since my (now 4) boy was born I have shot a large percentage of my "happy snaps" of him with a film camera. Finish the film, go to the local lab, get some prints to put straight in an album with a CD to email selections to friends and family. Bit of an effort? Yep and happy to do so.

Whenever I get the big "work" camera out the shots inevitably go to the back of the line behind the paying clients!

I shudder when I am out and about watching people capture moments on their camera phones - what do they do next? Bet they don't back them up anywhere, then they change or lose the phone - where are the photos? History gone, it's once time has passed that those images become precious.

Secondly, in my younger years (only the mid-80's though!) I was living and working away from my friends and family. The core group of 4 of my friends and I would write to each other without fail, each week - it might have been 4 lines or 4 pages, but we looked forward to what would appear in our letterboxes.

Fast forward ten or so years, one of the guys was away from all of us living and working. Email was now the means to communicate, a few computer purchases later and Eudora was dumped for Mail etc etc.

We lost him in an accident and suddenly those emails at once became precious and the victims of my technology upgrades. The content, more considered than those early written letters was gone.

I still have those old letters as do my friends and fortunately I have a wonderful visual archive of us growing up and being "boys".

I know you've discussed this issue at least twice before, and I'm in full agreement with your stance.

As for the readers who've said you "shouldn't be taking home movies at all" -- isn't it remarkable how many people think they have the know-how and license to run other people's lives? I turned 70 last week, and I still can't get over my puzzlement at this. I guess I never will.

By the way -- has your film editor friend tried using Twitter or some other social resource to seek somebody, somewhere, with the machine to rescue her first movie? Surely somebody must exist who'd do it for a modest fee, or even free of charge.

Good, thoughtful article.

The world is heading more and more into the impersonal abyss of on-line computing, blog posts (no offense to yours), texting, YouTube, and the like. We're forgetting how to communicate face to face. Eventually we're going to all turn into sedentary beings with mind connections to the internet.

Last night my 9-year old son wanted the family to use Google Chat on the three computers in our home to communicate with each other...in the same home. Forget about sitting around the kitchen table and playing a game - this was way cooler.

The first thing people do when they get into their cars is to glue the mobile phone to their ears. I guess they couldn't make the call from home. My daughter would rather e-mail someone than call (she doesn't even think about visiting her friend two doors down).

But this is where the home video brings us back to (an old) reality - before life as we know it got too busy and complex. Back when I was younger, only rich uncles had video cameras (Super 8s). So if we were lucky, he'd bring it along to events. And now we watch grainy films where life was simpler - carefree and full of energy and innocence.

The past tames my thirst for newer technology, and helps me put what we had (and what we still have) into perspective.

Thanks for writing the article.
I would LOVE to see and hear more documentation of my ancestors, more than the few surviving photographs, even the ones I've never met.

When my father turned 80, I gave him a VHS tape of his long deceased parents and sisters and himself when he was a strapping 20 year old.  It had been discovered in an old storage box and converted from a pre-Super 8 format.  He watched repeatedly, often in tears. I made copies for my cousin who  hadn't any moving images of her mother.  My children saw their great grandparents  and they became even more connected to their heritage.  We have tapes of beloved dogs and horses who died. Of children, grandchildren and friends.  And now our 5 year old grandson is starting to take videos. For us, this nearly century long collection of images is our family heirloom one that will last, in one form or another, when we're all ashes and dust.  It's our comet's tail.
